title: 111_hr5913
content: The "Text a Tip Act of 2010" establishes a pilot program for texting crime tips. The Attorney General can provide grants to law enforcement agencies for implementing an anonymous tip program via cell phone text messaging. The funds must be used for developing, expanding, or promoting the program, including expenses like salaries, training, technology, and public service promotion. Expenses for the program include salaries, training, technology, and promotion. The Federal share of the grant cannot exceed 75 percent of the program cost. Grant funds should supplement, not replace, non-Federal funds for program activities. Program requirements include the Federal share of the grant not exceeding 75 percent of the cost, with funds meant to supplement non-Federal funds for activities. A texting tip program of a State or local law enforcement agency eligible for a grant under this Act must comply with requirements such as administering the program, stripping incoming text messages of identifying information, ensuring the text tip is untraceable, not replacing existing hotlines, and providing sufficient training for law enforcement agency staff. The texting program for law enforcement agencies must ensure that text tips are untraceable, not replace existing hotlines, train personnel to respond to tips, be compatible with mobile phone providers, and include an unidentifiable code for follow-up information from tipsters. The texting program for law enforcement agencies should include an unidentifiable code for tipsters to send follow-up information, a feature to abort tips, and no additional fees imposed on tipsters' mobile phones. The law enforcement agency will not charge extra fees on the tipster's mobile phone, only standard messaging rates apply. They should also promote the texting program to encourage citizen participation, especially among youth. SEC. 4. APPLICATIONS. To request a grant under this Act, a State or local law enforcement agency must submit an application to the Attorney General with required information. Each application must certify that the program meets Act requirements. SEC. 5. REPORTS AND EVALUATIONS. SEC. 5. REPORTS AND EVALUATIONS. Recipients of grants must submit yearly reports on activities' effectiveness to the Attorney General. The Attorney General will then report to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. Defines "texting tip program" as a program allowing anonymous text tips to law enforcement, and "texting" as sending messages from a mobile phone. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for the Attorney General to carry out the Act is set at $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2011 to 2016.
